title: Gifted Hands: The Ben Carson Story
descriptions:
Based on the true story of Dr. Ben Carson, "Gifted Hands: The Ben Carson Story" (2009) is a biographical drama film that follows the life and career of an accomplished neurosurgeon. The film begins with a young Ben Carson (played by Jaishon Fisher and Gus Hoffman) growing up in poverty in Detroit, Michigan, with his mother, Sonya Carson (Kimberly Elise). Despite their financial struggles and Ben's poor academic performance, Sonya refuses to let her son fall victim to their circumstances. She instills in him a strong work ethic and a belief in the power of education, pushing him to read and complete additional schoolwork at home.

As Ben matures, he discovers a passion for science and medicine. With his mother's unwavering support, he excels academically, eventually earning a scholarship to attend Yale University for his undergraduate studies. During his time at Yale, Ben meets and marries his childhood sweetheart, Candy Rustin (Aunjanue Ellis), and the couple goes on to have three children together. Ben then attends the University of Michigan Medical School, where he develops a reputation for his exceptional surgical skills and innovative problem-solving abilities.

The film's central focus is on Ben's (Cuba Gooding Jr.) groundbreaking work as a pediatric neurosurgeon at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland. In 1985, Ben is presented with an unprecedented challenge when he is tasked with separating conjoined twins, Patrick and Benjamin Binder. The boys are joined at the back of the head, and their brains share critical blood vessels. Many surgeons before Ben had deemed the operation impossible, but he is determined to save both boys' lives.

Ben assembles a team of skilled medical professionals and begins meticulously planning the complex procedure. After months of preparation, the surgery is scheduled for 1987. The operation lasts for 22 hours, during which Ben and his team must overcome numerous complications and setbacks. In a tense and emotional climax, the twins are successfully separated, and both survive the surgery.

The film also explores the personal challenges Ben faces throughout his career, including his struggle with anger, which he eventually learns to control through prayer and self-reflection. He also experiences a devastating professional setback when one of his patients dies on the operating table, causing him to question his abilities as a surgeon. However, with the support of his wife and his faith, Ben perseveres and continues to make significant contributions to the field of neurosurgery.

In addition to the Binder twins' separation, "Gifted Hands" highlights several other groundbreaking operations that Ben performs, including the successful removal of a malignant tumor from the brain of a young girl, and the separation of another set of conjoined twins. These achievements, along with his numerous publications and lectures, establish Ben Carson as one of the world's leading neurosurgeons.

The film concludes with Ben being awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President George W. Bush in 2008, recognizing his significant contributions to medicine and his tireless efforts to inspire the next generation of physicians. "Gifted Hands: The Ben Carson Story" is an inspiring and uplifting portrayal of a man who overcame tremendous odds to achieve greatness and make a lasting impact on the world.
